name: (2E)-3-[(4-methylphenyl)amino]-1-(5,6,7,8-tetrahydronaphthalen-2-yl)prop-2-en-1-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1111

name: (2E)-3-[(4-methylphenyl)amino]-1-(5,6,7,8-tetrahydronaphthalen-2-yl)prop-2-en-1-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1111
Reason: The basic unit here is trans-chalcone, which has a melting point of approximately 56°C. The substitution of the phenyl ring in trans-chalcone with a 4-methyl group would normally increase the melting point due to the added bulk, increasing the molecular weight and providing more van der Waals forces. This increment is typically around +20°C. The additional 5,6,7,8-tetrahydronaphthalen-2-yl group adds significant molecular weight and complexity, further raising the melting point. This group can be expected to raise the melting point by around +70°C due to its rigid structure and additional van der Waals interactions. Lastly, the presence of the amino group in conjunction with the ketone could lead to hydrogen bonding within the molecule, which would typically add another +10°C to the melting point. Adding together the effects of the individual groups to the base value of trans-chalcone gives the calculated prediction value.
Prediction: 56 (for basic trans-chalcone) + 20 (4-methyl group) + 70 (tetrahydronaphthalen-2-yl group) + 10 (amino group's potential for hydrogen bonding) = 156°C

name: (2E)-3-[(4-methylphenyl)amino]-1-(5,6,7,8-tetrahydronaphthalen-2-yl)prop-2-en-1-one
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1111
Reason: The basic unit here is trans-chalcone, which has a melting point of 56°C. The addition of a 4-methyl group to the aromatic ring generally would increase the melting point due to larger molecular weight and increased van der Waals forces; this increment would typically be around +5-15°C. The tetrahydronaphthalen-2-yl group further adds to the molecular weight and has a rigid, bulky structure that increases intermolecular interactions, likely contributing around +50-60°C to the melting point. The amino group can form internal hydrogen bonds with the ketone, which would stabilize the solid state and could contribute around +10-15°C. Considering these effects, an additive prediction can be made for the compound's melting point.
